title: Community welcomed into Phoenix mosque
text:
Community welcomed into Phoenix mosque Phoenix community welcomed into mosque Audience members listen to a panel discussion at United Islamic Center of Arizona in Phoenix on Saturday, Feb. 18, 2017. The event was organized as an interfaith open house to educate the community about the Muslim faith. Ben Moffat/The Republic Ryan Santistevan , The Republic | azcentral.com 7:49 p.m. MT Feb. 18, 2017 Didmar Faja, the mosque's imam, said he hopes mosques statewide will open their doors and help dispel misconceptions. Didmar Faja, the imam of the United Islamic Center of Arizona, participates in a panel discussion at the center in Phoenix on Saturday, Feb. 18, 2017. The event was organized as an interfaith open house to educate the community about the Muslim faith. (Photo: Ben Moffat/The Republic) 2 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Despite the rainy weather Saturday, nearly 200 people took the United Islamic Center of Arizona up on its invitation to learn more about the Islamic faith. 
Mosque leaders invited the community to an open house in hopes of uniting the community and dispelling misconceptions. 
Didmar Faja, the mosque's imam, said he felt great about the turnout and thought it was a great opportunity to converse with people of different faiths. 
"I'm just so happy to see so many different faces," Faja said. "It's been a place where we can explain ourselves to the community." Syrian sweets sales offer bakery owner a way to give back, Arizona refugees chance to thrive 
He said he hopes the United Islamic Center of Arizona and other mosques throughout the state will continue to open their doors to the community in the future. 
Roxie Oliphant, of Glendale, said she has been troubled by the national conversation and believes President Donald Trump is judging a group of people without understanding them. 
"I think it's important for me to get out and get to know somebody face-to-face rather just to read what's in the fake news," Oliphant said. "I'm fascinated and thrilled that (UICA) did this. I think this is an important outreach." Phoenix church turns to paint to express hope for peace 
Uzma Jafri, speaker for Islamic Speakers Bureau of Arizona, was among the scheduled speakers at the event. Jafri said her organization goes around the state to educate people on Islam. She said she was not surprised by the turnout. 
"It just makes sense because this is America," Jafri said. "We are founded in the democratic principle of freedom of religion ... Our forefathers came here for that very same reason, to escape religious persecution and to have religious freedom. It just makes sense that there should be a plethora and multitude of people of different religions and different backgrounds in the same room." 
Phoenix City Councilwoman Thelda Williams attended. She said District 1 has the most refugees of any of the city's districts and believes there are many misconceptions about those of Muslim faith. 
"What I experience is people who want to be good neighbors," Williams said. "I am very proud of the people who live here. I don't care what the media says, it's not true in this Valley." 
Marina Dust, 24, is a member of the mosque. She said she was happy to see so many different people attend the open house. 
"With the recent rocky climate, I feel it's even more important today to reach out and educate as many people as you can and just be active in promoting peace, love and acceptance," she said. 
Joe Gosha, of Sun City, said he is part of an interfaith group that works with with at-risk youth in Phoenix. He also said he works with Syrian refugees and wanted to attend the open house to learn more about the people he works with. 
He said he wanted "to let the Muslim community know that there are native born people who are more than willing to enter into rational and open dialogue with newcomers to the country." Joe Gosha said he is at UICA's open house because he wants to show the Muslim community there are native born people open to talk@azcentral pic.twitter.com/vlbTHu5UdK â€” Ryan Santistevan (@SantistevanRyan) February 18, 2017 2 CONNECT COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://azc.cc/2lves5y TOP VIDEOS
